When you put Israel and Hamas on the same game board, the rules are completely rigged. Israel plays chess with international referees breathing down its neck, while Hamas flips the board, screams ‚Äúmartyrdom,‚Äù and somehow still gets points. Hamas can lose ten battles and claim victory just by surviving, while Israel can win militarily and still lose because the world expects it to act like a saint with a sniper rifle. That‚Äôs not a fair fight, it‚Äôs a rigged casino ‚Äî and Israel is the only one required to play by the house rules. Then you throw in the hostages, which is Hamas‚Äôs sick version of a side bet. Israel can‚Äôt ignore them ‚Äî every government has a sacred duty to bring its people home. But every deal, every prisoner swap, every pause proves hostage-taking works. That‚Äôs like paying off a kidnapper and then being shocked when kidnappings keep happening. Hamas knows exactly what they‚Äôre doing: hijacking Israel‚Äôs morality and weaponizing it against them. The more Israel cares about life, the more Hamas exploits it. And let‚Äôs be honest about ‚Äúeliminating Hamas.‚Äù Everyone says it like it‚Äôs a military checkbox, but it‚Äôs a mirage. Kill the men with the rockets, and new ones crawl out of the rubble. Burn down the tunnel system, and you‚Äôve just built Hamas 2.0 in the ashes. The smarter play is delegitimization ‚Äî strip Hamas of the one thing they can‚Äôt rebuild with Iranian cash: credibility with their own people. Remind Palestinians that billions went to tunnels, not schools. That their ‚Äúresistance‚Äù leaders live like kings while ordinary families live on crumbs. If Israel can contain Hamas militarily while exposing them politically, then the whole game changes. Hamas loses its cult appeal, and Israel stops being trapped in the same cycle of hostage swaps, airstrikes, and global scolding. That‚Äôs the only way the payoff matrix bends toward sanity.

Ethnocracy (Israel) ‚Ä¢ Definition: A state that has elections and grants citizenship rights to minorities, but its laws, symbols, and institutions are designed to preserve one ethnicity‚Äôs dominance. ‚Ä¢ Citizenship: Arab citizens of Israel can vote, run for office, and serve in parliament. ‚Ä¢ Immigration: The Law of Return gives automatic citizenship to Jews worldwide, but no reciprocal right for Palestinians. ‚Ä¢ Territorial split: Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza are under Israeli control but are not citizens, creating a dual system. ‚Ä¢ Core feature: Universal suffrage exists inside the recognized state, but the national identity and power structure remain explicitly Jewish. ‚∏ª Apartheid (South Africa, 1948‚Äì1994) ‚Ä¢ Definition: A system of explicit racial segregation and minority rule where the majority had no political rights whatsoever. ‚Ä¢ Citizenship: Black South Africans were denied citizenship and the right to vote in the national government. ‚Ä¢ Territorial split: ‚ÄúHomelands‚Äù (Bantustans) were created as pseudo-states to strip Black people of South African nationality. ‚Ä¢ Law: Entire legal system was based on racial separation in housing, education, jobs, and marriage. ‚Ä¢ Core feature: Permanent political exclusion of the majority population, enforced by race. ‚∏ª The Key Difference ‚Ä¢ Ethnocracy: You can vote if you‚Äôre a citizen, but the state is built for one ethnicity. ‚Ä¢ Apartheid: The majority couldn‚Äôt even be citizens, period. That‚Äôs why Israel calls itself a democracy ‚Äî minorities inside the 1948 borders can vote ‚Äî but critics argue that when you include the West Bank/Gaza under effective Israeli control, it looks closer to apartheid because millions of Palestinians live under the system without citizenship.

I love that idea of small communities with truly affordable housing. Young couples need starter homes but I would also suggest that housing with long leases, shared ownership and assured tenancies are also an option. Any development should be mixed developments, have community gardens, a meeting place and have tenants' councils to handle the day to day management. These are social housing models that are very successful in Scandanavia and northern Europe. Home ownership is not for everyone but our rental market is just one step away from transiency with unstable, insecure housing. This needs to change, especially for families with children who need a sense of community and social responsibility that they can't get when they're moving around all the time.
